h.en: The First Rung on the Ladder

s.gd: ’S e taigh beag a bha aig Pòl MacRath, le dà rùm agus clòsaid agus teàrr anairt air a mhullach.
s.en: Paul McRae had a little house, with two rooms and a closet and tarred cloth on its roof.

s.gd: Cha robh croit aige, ach bhiodh e a’ cur cliabh buntàta ann an croit a nàbaidh.
s.en: He did not have a croft, but he would plant a grid of potatoes in his neighbour’s croft.

s.gd: ’S e duine beag, lag agus caran uireasbhach a bh’ ann.
s.en: He was a little man, weak and somewhat defective.

s.gd: Cha dèanadh e iasgach no seòladh, oir cha robh am muir a’ tighinn air.
s.en: He wouldn’t do fishing or sailing, because the sea did not suit him.

s.gd: Cha robh a shlàinte ach meadhanach, agus dh’fhàg sin e ceum nas bochda na a’ mhòr-chuid sa bhaile, ach bha e glè mhùirneach aig Eilidh, a bhean, agus aig Seòras a mhac.
s.en: His health was but middling, and that left him a step poorer than the majority in the town, but he was very fond of Helen, his wife, and of George his son.

s.gd: Cha robh e ag iarraidh san t-saoghal ach dà rud: obair aotrom agus cead suidhe aig Bòrd an Tighearna.
s.en: He only wanted two things in the world: light work and permission to sit at the Lord’s Table.

s.gd: Bha Seòras còig bliadhna deug a dh’aois, agus ged a bha e a’ dèanamh glè mhath san sgoil, thàinig air a fàgail, oir bha an àrd-sgoil sa bhaile mhòr agus bha an t-airgead gann.
s.en: George was fifteen years old, and although he was doing very well at the school, he had to leave it, because the high school was in the city and money was scarce.

s.gd: Rinn e gàrradh beag air beulaibh an taighe, rud glè annasach sa bhaile bheag againne aig an àm.
s.en: He made a little garden in fron of the house, something very unusual in our little town at the time.

s.gd: Bhiodh e a’ dol air thuarastal a ghearradh mhònach ’s a spealadh arbhair, ach bha fios aige nach robh adhartas an sin idir.
s.en: He would go for wages to cut peat and to scythe corn, but he knew that there was no advancement there at all.

s.gd: Dh’fheumadh e faighinn air a’ chiad rong de dh’fhàradh obair bhuan.
s.en: He had to get on the first rung of the ladder of durable work.

s.gd: Chaidh Pòl uair is uair gu àitichean san robh obair air tòiseachadh, ach bha am mì-fhortan ga leantainn gus na thòisich companaidh a’ cur phìoban tron mhòintich airson uisge a’ bhaile mhòir.
s.en: Paul went time and again to places where work had started, but misfortune followed him until a company started laying pipes through the hills for the city’s water.

s.gd: Choisich Pòl seachd mìle dhan mhonadh agus lorg e maor na h-obrach ann an seada faisg air an rathad.
s.en: Paul walked seven miles to the hills and he found the foreman an a shed near the road.

s.gd: Dh’aithnich an duine sin e, oir bha e air fhaicinn aig àitichean eile a’ lorg car obrach.
s.en: That man recognised him, because he had seen him at other places looking for bits of work.

s.gd: “Tha an obair seo fada ro throm air do shon,” ars esan.
s.en: “This work is far too heavy for you,” he said.

s.gd: Bha Pòl air seo a chluinntinn tric, agus rinn e airson falbh, ach stad am maor e.
s.en: Paul had heard this often, and he made to leave, but the forema stopped him.

s.gd: Rinn e sgrìobhadh air pìos pàipeir agus thug e do Phòl e.
s.en: He made some writing on a piece of paper and he gave it to Paul.

s.gd: “Theirig gu talla a’ bhaile mhòir,” ars esan, “agus faic an duine sin.
s.en: “Go to the city hall,” he said, “and see that man.

s.gd: ’S e mo bhràthair a th’ ann agus tha e a’ lorg luchd-obrach an-dràsta.”
s.en: He is my brother and he is looking for workers at the moment.”

s.gd: Lorg Pòl an duine agus dh’innis e fàth a thurais.
s.en: Paul found the man and mentioned the purpose of his trip.

s.gd: “’N urrainn dhut tòiseachadh a-màireach?” ars an duine.
s.en: “Can you start tomorrow?” the man said.

s.gd: ’S e ceòl binn a bha seo ann an cluasan Phòil.
s.en: This was sweet music in Paul’s ears.

s.gd: Chaidh fear a chur còmhla ris a shealltainn dha far an robh an obair, agus thàinig e dhachaigh cho aoibhneach ’s gu robh càch a’ smaoineachadh gur e an deoch a ghabh e.
s.en: A man was sent with him to show him where the work was, and he came home so cheerful that the others thought that he had been drinking.

s.gd: “Dè an seòrsa obair a th’ ann?” dh’fhaighnich iad le chèile.
s.en: “What kind of work is it?” they asked in unison.

s.gd: “Gàirnealaireachd dhan Chomhairle,” ars esan.
s.en: “Gardening for the Council,” he said.

s.gd: “Priogadh is gearradh an fheòir.”
s.en: “Weeding and cutting the grass.”

s.gd: Thug Eilidh a-mach botal agus ghabh iad drama.
s.en: Helen took out a bottle and they had a dram.

s.gd: ’S fhada bho nach robh iad cho sona.
s.en: It was a long time since they had been so happy.

s.gd: O chionn fhada bha Pòl a’ bruidhinn air a dhol air adhart, mar a chanadh iad nuair a bhiodh duine a’ smaoineachadh air comanachadh, ach bha eagal air sin a dhèanamh.
s.en: For a long time Paul had been talking about going forward, as they would say when a man was thinking about taking communion, but he was afraid of doing that.

s.gd: Cha robh Eilidh idir cho fada air ais ri Pòl.
s.en: Helen was not at all as reticent as Paul.

s.gd: “Chan eil agad ach iarraidh,” ars ise.
s.en: “You only have to ask,” she said.

s.gd: “’S e ceum cudromach a th’ ann suidhe aig Bòrd an Tighearna,” ars esan.
s.en: “It is an important step to sit at the Lord’s Table,” he said.

s.gd: “Mas e, is iomadh gaoithean a tha suidhe aige,” ars ise.
s.en: “If so, many a windbag is sitting there,” she said.

s.gd: Mu dheireadh phut i Pòl gu bruidhinn ris an èildear.
s.en: Eventually she pushed Paul to speak to the elder.

s.gd: Gu mì-fortanach, b’ e seo am posta.
s.en: Unfortunately, this was the postman.

s.gd: “Tha mi coimhead gu bheil thu a’ dèanamh nam pools,” ars esan.
s.en: “I see that you do the pools,” he said.

s.gd: “Dh’fheumainn sin innse dhan mhinistear.”
s.en: “I would have to tell the minister that.”

s.gd: “Cha do choisinn mi càil a-riamh,” arsa Pòl.
s.en: “I never earned anything,” said Paul.

s.gd: “Chan eil gnothaich aig sin ris a’ chùis.
s.en: “That has nothing to do with the matter.

s.gd: Feumaidh tu a h-uile gòraich a leigeil seachad agus a h-uile litir a thig bho na pools a thoirt dhòmhsa gus an loisg mi iad.”
s.en: You must give up all nonsense and give every letter that comes from the pools to me so that I can burn them.”

s.gd: Bha Pòl deònach seo a dhèanamh, agus fhuair e gu Bòrd an Tighearna, ach lean Eilidh oirre a’ dèanamh nam pools, agus nuair a mhothaich am posta dha thubhairt i ris nach b’ e càil dhe ghnothaich e.
s.en: Paul was willing to do that, and he got to the Lord’s Table, but Helen continued to do the pools, and when the postman noticed it she said to him that it was none of his business.

s.gd: Ged nach robh e nise ceadaichte do Phòl beul a chur air deoch làidir, thug Eilidh a-mach am botal agus ghabh iad drama.
s.en: Although it was not now permitted to Paul to put mouth to strong drink, Helen took out the bottle and they had a dram.

s.gd: Bha iad cho sona ri dithis a bha san sgìre.
s.en: They were as happy a couple as was in the district.

s.gd: Am feasgar an dèidh do Phòl comanachadh, chunnaic Eilidh luch a’ ruith gu cùl an dreasair agus thòisich i air sgreuchail.
s.en: The evening after Paul took communion, Helen saw a mouse running to the back of the dresser nd she started to scream.

s.gd: Cha robh Seòras a-staigh agus thòisich Pòl a’ feuchainn ris an dreasair a ghluasad a-mach bhon bhalla.
s.en: George was not in and Paul started to try to move the dresser out from the wall.

s.gd: Thàinig grèim-cridhe air, agus bha e marbh nuair a ràinig e an t-ospadal.
s.en: He had a heart attack, and he was dead when he reached the hospital.

s.gd: Nuair a thill Eilidh leis an dust, dh’fhaighnich cuideigin dè bha Pòl a’ dèanamh nuair a thàinig an grèim-cridhe air agus thuirt i gur ann ag ùrnaigh a bha e.
s.en: When Helen returned with the body, someone asked what Paul was doing when he had the heart attack and she said that he had been praying.

s.gd: Sheall Seòras ri mhàthair agus mhothaich i dhan cheist a bha na shùilean.
s.en: George looked at his mother and she noticed the question that was in his eyes.

s.gd: Nuair a bha iad nan aonar thuirt i ris, “Tha uairean, a ghràidh, is ’s i òinseach a dh’innseadh an fhìrinn.
s.en: When they were alone she said to him, “There are time, dear, when it is a fool who tells the truth.

s.gd: Dè chanadh am baile nan cluinneadh iad gu robh d’ athair a’ ruagadh luch an dèidh dha comanachadh, agus sin air Là na Sàbaid.”
s.en: Whar would the town say if they would hear that your father was chading a mouse after taking communion, and that on a Sunday.”

s.gd: Thàinig fiamh a’ ghàire air aghaidh a’ bhalaich agus cha do chuir e coire idir air a mhàthair.
s.en: A smile came on the boy’s face and he did not blame his mother at all.

s.gd: Bha e a’ saoilsinn mòran dhe mhàthair, ach bha gaol aige air athair.
s.en: He thought a lot of his mother, but he loved his father.
